 Ok, I apologize--I thought the comment was yours, and not the authors, because there were no quotes around it or anything and the part was way, way down buried in the article. Now that I've re-read the article carefully, I see you were quoting it.  I certainly would still take issue with the author that the comment is relevant at all. At one time, nearly everyone in the country supported slavery, and therefore every group out there, religious or otherwise, that was around a long time ago would have a history there of "supporting evil". To be fair, the SBC apologized several years ago for its origins as well as the fact it had been too slow to to support civil rights. To continue holding something over someone's head that happened in another entire century, a very long time ago is a very weak and silly thing to do, IMO. I'm certainly not southern baptist, and there are a lot of things they do I don't agree with. But to hold the fact they once supported slavery over their heads is like blaming the current, modern-day descendants of John Wilkes Booth for the assassination of Lincoln. It's just stupid, frankly. Personally, I think integrity in writing is important, and when an author throws in a phrase like that, even as small and unassuming as it appears to be, it becomes hard to take their writing very seriously, for me anyway.
